properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog continues today. Dense fog persists over portions of the area near noon today. Patchy freezing drizzle also remains possible with temperatures hovering near the freezing mark. Roads and walkways may become icy and slippery. Conditions should briefly improve this afternoon but dense fog is expected to reform over portions of the region again this evening and then persist into tonight. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-20T08:13:44-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-19T16:14:44-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0778391987.2019
Area: Armstrong - Auden - Wabakimi Park, Beardmore - Jellicoe - Macdiarmid, Gull Bay - Black Sturgeon Lake, Nakina - Aroland - Pagwa, Geraldton - Longlac - Caramat, Manitouwadge - Hornepayne, Nipigon - Rossport, Marathon - Schreiber, White River - Dubreuilville, Wawa - Pukaskwa Park
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions are expected to begin tonight along the Hudson Bay coast. A low pressure system will bring snow and blowing snow to Arviat, Whale Cove, and Rankin Inlet. While the snow falls, north winds gusting as high as 80 km/h will create blizzard conditions with near-zero visibility in blowing snow. The blizzard condition are expected to last until Thursday morning, when winds will abate and visibility will improve. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-20T07:06:46-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-19T15:07:46-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1957679857.2019
Area: Arviat, Rankin Region including Whale Cove
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Precautionary Drinking Water Advisory For The Northern Village Of Ile-A-La Crosse.
properties.Summary:
Description: Due to a ruptured water main, A Precautionary Drinking Water Advisory has been issued for Northern Village of Ile-a-la Crosse. This advisory is for the Northern Village of Ile-a-la Crosse and for any individuals who may access water the Ile-a-la Crosse water system. This advisory is in effect until the water is deemed completed safe.
Expires: 2019-11-26T15:00:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: SK Ile a la Crosse, 2019-11-19T11:09:35-06:00, DF6BC5B6-7111-F829-8DB5-09B8F6105120
Area: Northern Village of Ile-a-la Crosse
properties.Author: SK Ile a la Crosse

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Patchy freezing rain today. Light to patchy freezing rain is expected near noon. The freezing rain may become mixed with snow at times, but is expected to last through the early part of the afternoon. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-20T01:59:50-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-19T15:49:50-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3039740133.2019
Area: Maxville - Alexandria, Cornwall - Lancaster, Prescott and Russell
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard beginning late overnight and lasting most of Wednesday. A low pressure system currently in northern Manitoba will move into southwestern Hudson Bay this evening and intensify tonight and Wednesday as it tracks slowly northeastward. Snow which has already moved into Arviat will become heavier throughout the day today, while northeast winds will strengthen tonight. The worst conditions will be late overnight and Wednesday morning with near zero visibility in snow and blowing snow. The snow will gradually taper off later on Wednesday allowing visibilities to slowly improve during the late afternoon or evening. Total snowfalls of 15 to 20 cm are likely. Rankin Inlet and Chesterfield Inlet will also be impacted by this system, although at this point it appears that the worst conditions will be at Arviat. Please listen for updated watches and warnings as this system moves into the area. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-20T01:29:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-19T09:30:41-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3967948426.2019
Area: Arviat
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:

To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A low pressure system tracking across the northern United States will continue spreading snow into southern Saskatchewan late this afternoon. Snow at times heavy tonight will taper off to light by Wednesday morning as the system moves toward the Dakotas. Total accumulations of 10 to 15 cm are likely over much of the Shaunavon and Assiniboia regions with slightly lesser amounts toward Estevan and Carlyle. Snowfall amounts will diminish quickly to the north of the Trans-Canada Highway. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-20T13:06:40-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-19T21:07:40-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0656319006.2019

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. A strong frontal system will move into Alaska today and reach the northern Yukon tonight. Snow will begin later this afternoon and as the system nears, winds of 70 km/h are forecast to develop. The snow and wind will combine to produce blizzard conditions tonight. The blizzard will end by early Wednesday morning when winds ease. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-20T05:00:22-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-19T13:01:22-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1233834889.2019
Area: Dempster
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant wintry weather is expected later this week. Possible Snowfall: 15 to 25 cm Locations: inland portions of most of Newfoundland. Time Span: Thursday morning to Friday afternoon. Remarks: A developing storm is forecast to bring wintry weather to the Island later this week. At this time it appears much of Newfoundland's interior will see a prolonged wet, heavy snowfall event with gusty northeasterly winds. The highest snowfall accumulations should be in the Island's interior, with more of a mixture of snow and rain the closer you get to the coast. Along Newfoundland's east coast, precipitation will fall mostly as rain. Some uncertainty still remains with this system, updates will be provided as the scenario becomes more clear. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-20T11:29:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-19T19:30:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3128864913.2019

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. Time span: tonight until Wednesday morning. Locations: Northern Peninsula East as well as Port Saunders and the Straits. Remarks: Snow over the Northern Peninsula will ease briefly near midnight before a second, less extensive, round of snow begins overnight. The snow will then taper off Wednesday morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-20T11:24:58-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-19T19:25:58-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4252204756.2019
Area: Northern Peninsula East, Port Saunders and the Straits
properties.Author: Environment Canada
